Provision.Text: Whereas the annexed Vessel Safety Certificates Regulations set out an amendment to the Navigation Safety Regulations, 2020, which establishes additional or complementary standards to those set out in the International Convention for the Safety of Life At Sea of 1974 and the Protocol of 1988 relating to the Convention, and the Administrator in Council is satisfied that those standards meet the objectives of the Convention and Protocol;

Therefore, His Excellency the Administrator of the Government of Canada in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport and the Minister of Natural Resources with respect to the provisions of the annexed Regulations other than sections 21 to 27, on the recommendation of the Minister of National Revenue with respect to that section 21, of the Minister of Labour with respect to those sections 22 to 24 and of the Minister of Transport with respect to those sections 25 to 27, makes the annexed Vessel Safety Certificates Regulations pursuant to

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Canada Pension Plana;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: section 157b of the Canada Labour Codec;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: section 27d of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992e; and

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: subsection 35(1)f, sections 77g, 100h and 120i, paragraph 136(1)(f)j, sections 190k and 207l and paragraphs 244(a), (f)m and (h)n of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001o.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Canada Shipping Act, 2001. (Loi)
inland voyage means a voyage that is not a sheltered waters voyage and is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the inland waters of Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the inland waters of Canada together with any part of a lake or river forming part of the inland waters of Canada that lies within the United States, or on Lake Michigan. (voyage en eaux internes)

Definition.Text: inland waters of Canada means all the rivers, lakes and other navigable fresh waters within Canada, and includes the St. Lawrence River as far seaward as a straight line drawn

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from Cap-des-Rosiers to Pointe Ouest, Anticosti Island; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from Anticosti Island to the north shore of the St. Lawrence River along longitude 63°W. (eaux internes du Canada)

Definition.Text: Minister means the Minister of Transport. (ministre)
near coastal voyage, Class 1 means a voyage

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is not a sheltered waters voyage, an inland voyage or a near coastal voyage, Class 2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is between places in Canada, the United States (except Hawaii), Saint Pierre and Miquelon, the West Indies, Mexico, or Central America, or on the northeast coast of South America, including on any navigable waters connected with that coast; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: during which a vessel is always

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: north of latitude 6°N, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 200 nautical miles or less from shore or above the continental shelf. (voyage à proximité du littoral, classe 1)

Definition.Text: near coastal voyage, Class 2 means a voyage

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is not a sheltered waters voyage or an inland voyage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: during which a vessel is always

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 25 nautical miles or less from shore in waters contiguous to Canada, the United States (except Hawaii) or Saint Pierre and Miquelon, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 100 nautical miles or less from a place of refuge. (voyage à proximité du littoral, classe 2)

Definition.Text: sheltered waters voyage means a voyage that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in Canada on a river above tidal waters or on a lake, where it is impossible for a vessel to be more than 2.5 nautical miles from the closest shore;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the waters listed in column 1 of Schedule 1 during the period specified in column 2; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: made by a ferry between two or more points listed in column 1 of Schedule 2 during the period specified in column 2. (voyage en eaux abritées)

Definition.Text: SOLAS means the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974, and the Protocol of 1988 relating to the Convention, as amended from time to time. (SOLAS)
unlimited voyage means a voyage that is not a sheltered waters voyage, an inland voyage, a near coastal voyage, Class 2 or a near coastal voyage, Class 1. (voyage illimité)

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of interpreting the provisions of SOLAS that are incorporated by reference into these Regulations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “should” is to be read as “must” and any recommendation or suggestion is to be read as an obligation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Administration” is to be read as “Minister”;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “ship” is to be read as “vessel”; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “survey” is to be read as “inspection”.

Subsection.Text: In the event of an inconsistency between a provision in SOLAS and a provision in these Regulations, the provision in these Regulations prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.
These Regulations apply in respect of Canadian vessels everywhere and foreign vessels in Canadian waters.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Activities relating to oil or gas
Subsection.Text: These Regulations apply in respect of a vessel referred to in subsection (1) that is capable of engaging in the drilling for, or the production, conservation or processing of, oil or gas.

Section.MarginalNote: Prescribed class — section 119 of the Act
Section.Text: A Canadian vessel in respect of which these Regulations apply is a vessel of a prescribed class for the purposes of section 119 of the Act.
This Division applies in respect of Canadian vessels that are Safety Convention vessels.
A vessel must hold the applicable safety certificates issued under section 7 to engage on a voyage.

Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a vessel, the Minister must issue the applicable safety certificates referred to in SOLAS to the vessel if the vessel meets the requirements of regulations made under Part 4 of the Act in respect of the following that apply to the vessel when it is engaged in its intended service:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s structure and its main and auxiliary machinery, boilers and other pressure vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: watertight subdivision arrangements and details;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subdivision load lines;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: structural fire protection, fire safety systems and appliances and fire control plans;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: life-saving appliances and equipment for lifeboats, life rafts and rescue boats;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: line-throwing appliances and radio installations used in life-saving appliances;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: radio installations;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: shipborne navigational equipment, means of embarkation for pilots, and nautical charts and publications; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: lights, shapes and means of making distress and sound signals.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a safety certificate must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel undergoes all inspections required in respect of the applicable certificate under Part B of Chapter I of SOLAS; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if Part B of Chapter I of SOLAS requires that the certificate be endorsed following the inspection, the certificate is endorsed by the Minister, in accordance with that Part, to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate continue to be met.

Section.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a vessel, the Minister must issue an exemption certificate to the vessel if an exemption has been granted by the Marine Technical Review Board in accordance with section 28 of the Act in respect of the requirements that must be met for the issuance of a safety certificate under section 7.

Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a vessel for a continuous synopsis record referred to in Regulation 5 of Chapter XI-1 of SOLAS, the Minister must issue the record to the vessel in accordance with that Regulation.
The application must contain the information referred to in Regulation 5.3 of Chapter XI-1 of SOLAS.
If there is a change that affects the information that is contained in the continuous synopsis record, the authorized representative must, as soon as feasible,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inform the Minister in writing of the change;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit a new application for an updated version of the continuous synopsis record; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the information referred to in Regulations 5.3.4 to 5.3.12 of Chapter XI-1 of SOLAS, amend the continuous synopsis record to reflect the change.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Prohibition from altering continuous synopsis record
Subsection.Text: Subject to paragraph (3)(c), the authorized representative must ensure that the continuous synopsis record is not altered or defaced and that any information contained in it is not modified or removed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vessel transferred — continuous synopsis record on board
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative must ensure that the continuous synopsis record is left on board when the vessel is transferred to the flag of another state, is sold or another company assumes the responsibility for its operation.

If a vessel is transferred to the flag of another state, the authorized representative must, as soon as feasible after the transfer, inform the Minister of the name of the state to allow the Minister to forward to that state a copy of each continuous synopsis record issued by the Minister to that vessel.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a safety certificate must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all safety certificates that are required by section 6 are kept on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any document that is required to be attached to the certificates under SOLAS and the regulations made under Part 4 of the Act is kept on board;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any exemption certificate that is referred to in section 8 is kept on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the authorized representative has applied for an updated continuous synopsis record under paragraph 9(3)(b) and the authorized representative has not yet received the updated record, a copy of the application is kept on board.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Vessels that are not Safety Convention Vessels

Subsection.Text: This Division applies in respect of the following Canadian vessels that are not Safety Convention vessels:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessels of 15 gross tonnage or less that carry more than 12 passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: vessels of more than 15 gross tonnage.

Subsection.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pleasure craft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: vessels to which the Special-purpose Vessel Regulations apply;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: human-powered vessels; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that does not have a mechanical means of propulsion and does not carry persons, dangerous chemicals in bulk or oil in bulk on board.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (2)(d), dangerous chemical has the same meaning as in subsection 1(1) of the Vessel Pollution and Dangerous Chemicals Regulations.

Section.Text: A vessel must hold the applicable safety certificates issued under section 13 to engage on a voyage.

Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a vessel, the Minister must issue the applicable safety certificates to the vessel if the vessel meets the requirements of regulations made under Part 4 of the Act in respect of the following that apply to the vessel when it is engaged in its intended service:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s structure and its main and auxiliary machinery, boilers and other pressure vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: watertight subdivision arrangements and details;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subdivision load lines;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: structural fire protection, fire safety systems and appliances and fire control plans;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: life-saving appliances and equipment for lifeboats, life rafts and rescue boats;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: line-throwing appliances and radio installations used in life-saving appliances;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: shipborne navigational equipment, means of embarkation for pilots, and nautical charts and publications; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: lights, shapes and means of making distress and sound signals.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a safety certificate that is valid for more than one year must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is inspected no later than a date that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: determined by the Minister after considering the vessel’s type and size and the class of voyage on which the vessel may engage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: indicated on the certificate at the time it is issued; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the certificate is endorsed by the Minister following the inspection to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate continue to be met.

Subsection.Text: A vessel that holds a safety certificate for an inland voyage may also engage on a sheltered waters voyage that is within the waters described in paragraphs (a) and (b) of the definition inland voyage.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Near coastal voyage, Class 2 safety certificate
Subsection.Text: A vessel that holds a safety certificate for a near coastal voyage, Class 2 may also engage on a sheltered waters voyage and an inland voyage.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Near coastal voyage, Class 1 safety certificate
Subsection.Text: A vessel that holds a safety certificate for a near coastal voyage, Class 1 may also engage on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a sheltered waters voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an inland voyage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a near coastal voyage, Class 2.

Subsection.Text: A vessel that holds a safety certificate for an unlimited voyage may also engage on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a sheltered waters voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an inland voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a near coastal voyage, Class 2; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a near coastal voyage, Class 1.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a safety certificate must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all safety certificates that are required by section 12 are kept on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any document that is required to be attached to the certificates under the regulations made under Part 4 of the Act is kept on board.

Section.Text: If the Minister determines that terms and conditions on a safety certificate issued to a vessel are necessary based on the vessel’s construction, equipment, stability and design criteria, the Minister may impose terms and conditions that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restrict a vessel’s intended service; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: limit the voyage on which the vessel may engage after considering the following criteria with respect to the vessel’s intended area of operation:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: wave height,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: wind velocity,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: current,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: visibility,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: proximity to assistance, a place of refuge or shore,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation hazards,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: communications coverage,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: average depth of the water,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: water temperature,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: air temperature,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: maximum tide range, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: ice conditions.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a Canadian vessel must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if an inspection report indicates that a requirement referred to in subsection 7(1) or 13(1) has not been met and a period is set out in the inspection report to comply with the requirement, submit to the Minister, within that period,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a report, in the form specified by the Minister, that specifies the measures taken to comply with the requirement, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: documents demonstrating the measures taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a modification or an alteration made to the vessel, or damage caused to the vessel, results in the vessel no longer meeting all of the requirements referred to in subsection 7(1) or 13(1), submit to the Minister, without delay,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a report, in the form specified by the Minister, that describes the modification, alteration or damage and specifies the measures subsequently taken to comply with the requirements, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: documents demonstrating the measures taken.

Subsection.Text: Following the submission of the report and the documents, the authorized representative must ensure that they receive a written confirmation from the Minister that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate continue to be met.

In order to provide the confirmation, the Minister must review the report and the documents provided by the authorized representative and, if the Minister determines that it is necessary, inspect the vessel.
The authorized representative of a foreign vessel that is a Safety Convention vessel must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all safety certificates that are required by SOLAS are kept on board,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any document that is required by SOLAS to be attached to a safety certificate is kept on board,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any exemption certificate that is referred to in Regulation 12(a)(vii) of Part B of Chapter I of SOLAS is kept on board, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if the authorized representative has applied to its flag state for an updated continuous synopsis record and the authorized representative has not yet received the updated record, a copy of the application is kept on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be able to demonstrate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificates and documents referred to in subparagraphs (a)(i) to (iii) continue to be met.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a foreign vessel that holds a safety certificate that is required by SOLAS must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel undergoes all inspections required in respect of the applicable certificate under Part B of Chapter I of SOLAS; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if Part B of Chapter I of SOLAS requires that the certificate be endorsed following the inspection, the certificate is endorsed, in accordance with that Part, to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate continue to be met.

Section.MarginalNote: Vessels that are not Safety Convention vessels
Section.Text: The authorized representative of a foreign vessel that is not a Safety Convention vessel must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a document issued by or under the authority of the vessel’s flag state that indicates that the vessel complies with the safety requirements of its flag state is kept on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be able to demonstrate that the requirements for the issuance of that document continue to be met; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel’s design, construction and equipment meet a level of safety that is equivalent to or higher than that required by regulations made under Part 4 of the Act for Canadian vessels that are of a similar size and type.

Heading.Label: PART 3
Heading.TitleText: Transitional Provision, Consequential and Related Amendments, Repeals and Coming into Force

Section.MarginalNote: Certificates issued under Vessel Certificates Regulations
Section.Text: A certificate issued under the Vessel Certificates Regulations that is valid immediately before the day on which these Regulations come into force is deemed to have been issued under these Regulations.

TitleText.XRefExternal: Maritime Occupational Health and Safety Regulations
Administrative Monetary Penalties and Notices (CSA 2001) Regulations
Vessel Pollution and Dangerous Chemicals Regulations
Board of Steamship Inspection Scale of Fees

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Hull Inspection Regulations20;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Classed Ships Inspection Regulations, 198821; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Vessel Certificates Regulations22.

Section.Text: These Regulations come into force on the day on which they are published in the Canada Gazette, Part II.

entry.Emphasis: Lake Huron and Georgian Bay Region

row.entry: North Channel in Lake Huron east of a line drawn from Bruce Mines to De Tour Reef Light, Michigan, and west of a line drawn from Red Rock Point at the east end of Killarney to Cape Smith on Manitoulin Island

The waters of Parry Sound and the waters off the Thirty Thousand Islands east of a line drawn from the southwest end of Franklin Island to the northeast end of Sandy Island and from the southwest end of Sandy Island to the east side of Fryingpan Island
Colpoy’s Bay southwest of a line drawn from Cameron Point to Gravelly Point

Georgian Bay east of a line drawn to the north from at a point at 44°51.5′N, 80°00.5′W to the southern tip of Giants Tomb Island and south of a line drawn from the northern tip of Giants Tomb Island to Cognashene Point, including the waters of Severn Sound and the harbours of Penetanguishene and Midland
Lake Huron south of the U.S. navigation light #7 (Lake Huron Cut), west of longitude 82°24′W and north of the Fort Gratiot Light, Michigan
St. Clair River and Detroit River south of Fort Gratiot Light and north of latitude 42°03′N at Bar Point, but not including Lake St. Clair

St. Marys River south of a line drawn from North Gros Cap to Point Iroquois, Michigan, and north of a line drawn from De Tour Village, Michigan, to Barbed Point on Drummond Island, Michigan, but not east of a line drawn from Chippewa Point on Drummond Island to Big Point on St. Joseph Island
Inner Bay and Long Point Bay west of a line drawn from Port Dover Harbour to the southern tip of Long Point (42°33′N, 80°03′W)

The waters between the mainland shore and Toronto Island (Toronto Inner Harbour) bounded in the west by the Western Gap by a line drawn from a point at 43°37.86′N, 79°24.13′W to a point at 43°37.82′N, 79°24.08′W, and bounded in the east by the Eastern Gap by a line drawn from a point at 43°37.87′N, 79°20.96′W to a point at 43°37.99′N, 79°20.83′W

Lake Ontario, excluding the waters referred to in item 9, north of a line drawn from a point at 43°36.99′N, 79°28.59′W to a point at 43°35.95′N, 79°23.13′W and thence to a point at 43°36.78′N, 79°20.65′W
Presqu’ile Bay near Brighton west of a line drawn north from Presqu’ile Point

Bay of Quinte and North Channel, including connecting waters, bounded in the east by a line drawn from Pleasant Point on the Cressy Point peninsula to Pig Point on Amherst Island, thence along the shoreline to the eastern end of Amherst Island (44°10.8′N, 76°37.1′W), thence to Salmon Island and thence to Carruthers Point near Kingston

Lake Ontario near Wolfe Island(a)east of a line drawn from Nine Mile Point on Simcoe Island to Long Point on Wolfe Island and thence to Bear Point on Wolfe Island; and(b)west of a line drawn from Staley Point in Boat Channel northwest to a point at 44°09.91′N, 76°31.16′W on Simcoe Island

St. Lawrence River, other than the portions of Lake St. Francis that are in Quebec,(a)northeast of a line drawn from Carruthers Point near Kingston, to Salmon Island, thence to Snake Island and thence to Nine Mile Point on Simcoe Island;(b)northeast of a line drawn from Staley Point in Boat Channel northwest to a point at 44°09.91′N, 76°31.16′W on Simcoe Island; and(c)north of a line drawn from the southern point of Wolfe Island at Bear Point to Tibbetts Point, United States
Cook’s Bay on Lake Simcoe south of a line drawn from Jacksons Point to the northern tip of Fox Island and thence to Leonards Beach (44°20.3′N, 79°32′W)
Kempenfelt Bay on Lake Simcoe west of a line drawn from a point at 44°26.1′N, 79°31.5′W to Big Bay Point
Rice Lake and Lake Couchiching on the Trent-Severn Waterway
Lake of the Woods north of latitude 49°N
Missisquoi Bay on Lake Champlain north of latitude 45°01′N
St. Lawrence River between Trois-Rivières and Saint-Jean-de-l’Île-d’Orléans, bounded in the west by longitude 72°40′W and in the east by longitude 70°53′W
Saguenay River west of a line drawn from Pointe Noire (48°07.433′N, 69°42.979′W) to Pointe Rouge (48°08.098′N, 69°42.08′W)
Lake Saint-Pierre bounded in the west by longitude 72°58′W and in the east by longitude 72°40′W
Mingan Archipelago bounded in the west by longitude 64°14′W, in the east by longitude 63˚27′W and in the south by latitude 50°10′N
Sept Îles Bay bounded by a line drawn from a point at 50°08.5′N, 66°31.5′W to a point at 50°04.5′N, 66°23.5′W, thence to a point at 50°08′N, 66°15′W and thence to a point at 50°12.8′N, 66°13.5′W

Grande Entrée Bay (Magdalen Islands), including Grande Entrée Lagoon, bounded by a line drawn from the northern light on the wharf at Grande-Entrée (47°33.377′N, 61°33.793′W) to the eastern edge of Dune du Sud (47°33.547′N, 61°35.454′W)

Plaisance Bay (Magdalen Islands) bounded in the east by a line drawn from Moine-Qui-Prie Cape (47°23.434′N, 61°46.395′W) to the northern end of La Black Head Point on Île d’Entrée (47°17.295′N, 61°41.396′W), thence along the west shore of Île d’Entrée to the wharf at point 47°16.643′N, 61°43.1′W and thence to the northeastern tip of Dune Sandy Hook (47°16.135′N, 61°46.779′W)
The waters lying within a radius of five nautical miles from the wharf at Percé (48°31.219′N, 64°12.652′W)
Gaspé Harbour bounded in the east by longitude 64°24.8′W from f Sandy Beach Point to the north shore of Gaspé Harbour
Gaspé Bay bounded in the east by longitude 64°10′W
Chaleur Bay, including the Restigouche River, bounded in the east by longitude 66°05′W

Bras d’Or Lake, Great Bras d’Or Channel and connecting waters(a)inside a line drawn from Carey Point (46°17.6′N, 60°25′W) to Noir Point (46°17.45′N, 60°24.8′W);(b)inside a line drawn from Point Aconi (46°18.72‘N, 60°17.23′W) to Alder Point (46°18.67‘N, 60°16.97‘W); and(c)north of the seaward end of St. Peters Canal (45°39.2′N, 60°52.15′W)
Annapolis Basin and Digby Gut inside a line drawn from Point Prim Lighthouse (45°41.5′N, 65°47.2′W) to Victoria Beach at the entrance to Digby Gut (45°41.3′N, 65°45.5′W)
Halifax Harbour and the waters inside a line drawn from the triangulation station on Osborne Head (44°36.75′N, 63°25.35′W) to the eastern end of Chebucto Head (44°30.15′N, 63°31.2′W)
LaHave River north of a line drawn from a point at 44°16.03′N, 64°19.83′W to a point at 44°15.8′N, 64°22.1′W

The waters inside a line drawn from the eastern end of Country Harbour Head (45°07.42′N, 61°38.73′W) to a point at Harbour Island (45°08.2′N, 61°37′W) and a line drawn from 45°08.3′N, 61°36.16′W, near Burke Point, to the light near Darby Point
St. Anns Harbour inside a line drawn from Bar Point (46°17.8′N, 60°31.91′W) to a point at St. Anns Beach (46°17.72′N, 60°32.52′W), including the waters of Jersey Cove
Inner Sydney Harbour south of a line drawn from Amelia Point (46°09.04′N, 60°13.26′W) to Battery Point (46°09.05′N, 60°12.2′W)
St. Margarets Bay north of a line drawn from Tilley Point (44°32.3′N, 64°01′W) to Mackerel Point (44°32.118′N, 63°56.8′W)

Saint John Harbour inside the southern breakwater and inside a line drawn from the southern end of the northern breakwater (45°15.42′N, 66°02.72′W) to the eastern point of Partridge Island (45°14.42′N, 66°03.08′W)
Shediac Harbour west of a line drawn from Pointe-du-Chêne (46°14.48′N, 64°30.7′W) to Caissie Cape (46°18.75′N, 64°30.6′W)

Miramichi Bay west of a line drawn from the eastern shore of Neguac Beach (47°13.1′N, 65°01.3′W) to the eastern shores of Portage and Fox islands and thence to the western point of Preston Beach (47°04.45′N, 64°57.05′W)
Nepisiguit Bay inside a line drawn from Youghall Point (47°39.3′N, 65°37.42′W) to Carron Point (47°39.1′N, 65°37.39′W)
Dalhousie Harbour and Restigouche River west of a line drawn from Miguasha Point (48°04.06′N, 66°17.6′W), Quebec, to the mouth of the Charlo River (47°59.3′N, 66°17.2′W)
